Chem. 1994; 269: 28752-28756Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we have demonstrated that 2 Trp residues at positions 174 and 243 of EGK play an important role in the substrate binding and/or the catalytic activity. The conclusion is based upon (a) Trp174 and Trp243 interact with cellotriose, an inhibitor of EGK; (b) the two Trp residues are oxidized byN-bromosuccinimide in a stepwise way, i.e.Trp174 was oxidized first with a retention of 56% of the original activity, followed by the oxidation of Trp243 with complete loss of activity; (c) substitution of Trp174 and Trp243 with Tyr residues results in a decrease in the specific activity to 49 and 8%, respectively; (d) K m values of the two mutant enzymes (W174Y, W243Y) increase five and eight times that of the wild-type enzyme, respectively; and (e) thek cat values of both mutant enzymes become one-fifth of that of the wild-type enzyme. In order to investigate microenvironments of these Trp residues, hydrogen-deuterium exchange experiments were carried out in the present study. The results obtained indicated that the hydrogen-deuterium exchange rates of the amide and indole protons of Trp174are faster than those of Trp243. Therefore, we suggest that the main and side chains of Trp174 are exposed to solvent and those of Trp243 are located in a hydrophobic microenvironment and are buried in the active site. It might be expected that the mutation at position 243 could cause a significant conformational change of the active site to reduce the enzymatic activity. Therefore, we conclude that the difference in the microenvironment between Trp174 and Trp243 is responsible for the difference in the specific activities observed between W174Y and W243Y. This can also explain the reason why Trp174 is more susceptible to oxidation byN-bromosuccinimide than Trp243 (20Kawaminami S. Ozaki K. Sumitomo N. Hayashi Y. Ito S. Shimada I. Arata Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 28752-28756Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In our previous study, the conserved carboxylate residues in all the endo-β-glucanases in family 8, Glu130, Asp191, Asp193, and Asp300 in EGK, are responsible for the catalytic reaction (18Ozaki K. Sumitomo N. Hayashi Y. Kawai S. Ito S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1207: 159-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). In order to investigate the role of these carboxylate residues in the enzymatic mechanism of EGK, we carried out measurements of pH dependence of the specific activities and pH titration experiments by using the wild-type and mutant enzymes, E130Q, D191N, D193N, and D300N. On the basis of the results from the pH dependence of the specific activities, it is clearly indicated that Glu130 and Asp191 play a crucial role in the enzymatic activity of EGK. The specific activities for E130Q and D191N are enormously reduced over the range of pH 4.2 to 8.0, no longer indicating any obvious pH dependence. In contrast, the pH-activity profiles for D193N and D300N are little affected, compared with that of wild-type EGK, although the specific activities for the mutants are reduced. Therefore, it is suggested that the mutations introduced at positions 193 and 300 cause less of a drastic change in the active site as those as positions 130 and 191. As shown in Fig. 5, the chemical shifts of the indole C2 protons of Trp174 and Trp243 of wild-type EGK are dependent upon the pH of the solvent. The results indicate that both the pK a values determined by the chemical shifts of the two Trp residues are approximately 5.5. This result strongly suggests that in the active site one or more acidic amino acid residues exist in close spatial proximity to Trp174 and Trp243. The mutation introduced at Glu130 or Asp191 of EGK induced drastic changes in the pH dependence of the chemical shifts of the indole C2 protons of both Trp174 and Trp243, indicating that Glu130 and Asp191 are located in the neighborhood of Trp174 and Trp243 in the active site. For [Trp]E130Q and [Trp]D191N (Fig. 5, b and c), no significant transition is observed for [Trp]EGK in the low pH range (Fig. 5 a), although it is expected that a transition due to pK a of Asp191 and Glu130 would be observed in the pH profile for [Trp]E130Q and [Trp]D191N, respectively. It is most likely that the pK a values of Asp191 in [Trp]E130Q and Glu130 in [Trp]D191N are below 4.0. On the basis of the results from the pH titration experiment, it is suggested that Glu130 and Asp191 are in close spatial proximity to Trp174 and Trp243 and that Glu130 and Asp191 interact with each other in the active site of EGK. This would increase the pK avalues of both Glu130 and Asp191 to 5.5, considering that the pK a values of 5.5 are only observed in the wild-type EGK not in either E130Q or D191N. It is observed that the chemical shifts for Trp174 and Trp243 of the wild-type EGK are significantly affected by the ionic strength of the sample solution. By lowering the concentration of NaCl from 150 mm to 0 mm, the entire pH profile of the chemical shifts for Trp174 and Trp243 of wild-type EGK shifted toward the high pH region, indicating that electrostatic interaction exists between Glu130 and Asp191 (data not shown). As shown in Fig. 5, d and e, the pH dependence of Trp174 and Trp243 for [Trp]D193N and [Trp]D300N indicate the pK a values are almost same as that for the wild-type enzyme. Therefore, we conclude that the replacements at Asp193 or Asp300 cause no effect on the pK a of Glu130 and Asp191 in the mutants. However, it is also indicated that the chemical shifts of Trp243 in both the mutants are slightly different from those for wild-type enzyme and are shifted to an upper field over the pH range 4.0 to 7.0, indicating that the mutations at Asp193 or Asp300 result in small structural changes in the active-site, which lead to some loss of enzymatic activity. This result is also in a complete agreement with the finding from the pH dependence of the specific activities for D193N and D300N that the pH-activity profiles for the mutants are quite similar to that of wild-type EGK, although the specific activities of the mutants are reduced. Although there is relatively a low amino acid sequence identity (27.7% within 397 amino acid residues) between EGK and CelA, the residues that are responsible for the enzymatic activity, including Trp174 and Trp243 in EGK, are conserved at the corresponding positions in CelA. It has been demonstrated that Trp132, Trp205, Glu95, Asp152, Asp154, and Asp259 in CelA correspond to Trp174, Trp243, Glu130, Asp191, Asp193, and Asp300 in EGK, respectively. Trp132 and Trp205 in CelA are located on the surface of the active site cleft (Fig.7). The indole NH proton of Trp132 in CelA is oriented to the outer direction, while that of Trp205 is directed toward the inside of the active site. Furthermore, both Glu95 and Asp152(Glu130 and Asp191 in EGK) are in close spatial proximity to Trp132 and Trp205(Trp174 and Trp243 in EGK) and Asp154 and Asp259 are far away from the active site. These observations are consistent with the results obtained in the present NMR study. We have indicated that the pH activity curve of EGK shows a very narrow pH range and the optimum pH value is 5.2 in the previous study (4Ozaki K. Ito S. J. Gen. Microbiol. 1991; 137: 41-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). No enzyme that possesses such the narrow pH-activity profile for O-(carboxymethyl)cellulase activity is known, except for endo- and exoglucanases from Trichoderma harzianum (28Sidhu M.S. Kalra M.K. Sandhu D.K. Folia Microbiol. 1986; 31: 293-302Crossref Scopus (14) Google Scholar). However, the pH dependence of the activity of the fungal enzymes is due to the instability of the enzymes at both low and high pH. A pair of carboxylates has required in the inversion mechanism of glycosyl hydrolases, one carboxylate residue acts as a general acid and the other as a general base (29Henrissat B. Davies G. Structure (Lond.). 1995; 3: 853-859Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1628) Google Scholar). The pK a values of the catalytic residues are the decisive factor of the pH-activity profile of the glycosyl hydrolase. Along with the fact that E130Q and D191N indicate no remarkable pH dependence of specific activity over the pH range 4.2 to 8.0, we conclude that Glu130 and Asp191, which are the catalytic residues in EGK, possess the same pK a value of 5.5, which explains the unusually narrow pH-activity profile of the EGK. As described in the introduction, Trp residues are found in the binding site in a number of glycosyl hydrolases. Therefore, the use of Trp residues as structural probes in stable isotope-aided NMR analysis can be a general method for the investigation of the enzymatic mechanism of glycosyl hydrolases.
